text: date: fri, 22 oct 1999 14:55:44 -0700 from: chris opie (cjo@mpx.com.au)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: making sense of computersthis is in reference to "making sense of computers ,"21.oct.99. this article is about making computers more responsive to humans by making them more aware of human emotion, for example with devices that measure human arousal and communicate that to the computer.i really think that such lines of research by n. negroponte and theother luminaries mentioned is pretty much beside the point except forspecial purposes (e.g., arousal measurement might be interesting in some game). i suppose that culturally i am opposed to such "emotive"communication because i see it as a sign of anti-intellectualism.for some people, thinking is just too hard, particularlyarticulating precisely what they want. they just want the world to agree with them. or, to put it slightly differently, i believe that computers are, in the end, about precise control. their power comes from being amplifiers of intelligence.the participants at the conference in question really seem to be evading the real issues of user frustration with computers. these are such things as poorly written, uninformative application manuals, and, of course, badly written software which crashes because, for instance, it has poor or non-existent error handling.come on everyone, get real!
